text: sometimes I'm craving chili and
sometimes I'm craving stew it occurred
to me that I could just make a chicken
chili stew and satisfy both and it
starts with thighs I like chicken thighs
because there are a lot more flavorful
than breasts and much cheaper season the
chicken thighs generously with salt and
pepper I have three and a half pounds of
chicken thighs here that's about 8 to 10
thighs depending on the size think we're
ready to start cooking have a pan
preheating over medium-high this is a 6
quart enameled cast iron which is great
for something like this want that nice
and hot and then to that about 2
teaspoons of safflower oil I'm searing
this in batches because I don't want to
crowd the pan if the pan is crowded with
the chicken unfortunately your chicken
is going to steam and not sear that
needs to brown on both sides
inside first and that takes about 10
minutes total these are looking and
smelling good and I think they're ready
to flip you can see that there's a lot
more fat in the pan now than when we
started that's because the thighs have
actually rendered some of their fat and
that's gonna give us even more flavor in
the stew these will just need a few
minutes on the other side and then we'll
put in a second batch okay and that's
the last of our chicken before we add
the aromatics
drain all but two tablespoons of the fat
from the pot that chicken has released a
lot of fat don't want quite all of it in
there so I like to just pour it all out
first and then add a little bit back in
that looks about right okay now for the
aromatics we have several aromatic
vegetables here the continued building
flavor into our stew you'll want a large
onion chopped that's about three cups
and three poblano chilies these are
milder Chili Peppers they can have a
little bit of kick but not too much just
give them a coarse chop and also garlic
four cloves minced that's about one and
a half tablespoons and our herb is fresh
oregano I love the smell of oregano so
beautiful just strip the leaves right
off the stalk and finely chop it
you'll want about a tablespoon of
lightly packed oregano looks like those
two sprigs of oregano make for almost an
exact tablespoon and then the beans it
would
via Chile without beans I like
cannellini either big creamy white beans
if you're using your hands of course
make sure they're clean and half of them
I'm putting in whole the other half mash
them into a paste but you can make very
quick work of this and you really want
this to be a totally smooth paste don't
be afraid to really get in there okay I
think we're ready to continue cooking
let's get these aromatics in the pot
return the pot to medium heat and start
by adding the onions poblanos and garlic
if these an occasional stir and let them
cook until the onions are softened
that'll take about five minutes the
vegetables are glossy and the onions
have picked up a little bit of color so
that tells me we're ready for the rest
of the aromatics the oregano that we
chopped earlier and it wouldn't be chili
without chili powder tablespoon goes in
stir these in and just cook them until
they're fragrant it's about 30 seconds
any longer and the chili powder and
oregano will scorch and not taste good
okay I'm smelling that chili powder and
oregano so the chicken goes back in and
they should fit nicely and roughly in a
single layer all right and for the
liquid a quart of chicken broth use
homemade if you have it otherwise you
can use low-sodium store-bought chicken
broth and you'll also want an equal
amount of water so that's gonna be four
cups oh yeah
crank that stovetop up to high heat
bring it to a boil then cover it reduce
the heat to low and let it simmer just
until the chicken is cooked through and
registers 165 degrees on a meat
thermometer that's gonna take about 8 to
10 minutes okay our chicken is fully
cooked so take those out and let them
cool slightly and then in the meantime
the beans can go in this is smelling so
wonderful now the mashed beans stir
those in first and they'll essentially
dissolve into the soup and help to
thicken it give that a little bit of a
stir and you'll see before our very eyes
starting to look more and more like a
chili stew that'll just take one minute
to sort of break down there and the
whole beans those can go in and raise
the heat just tie enough to get a simmer
again for about 10 minutes until it's
thickened slightly and in the meantime
we can shred our chicken let's let it
sit long enough so that it's cool enough
to handle I have a good kitchen hands so
it's not too hot for me to start
shredding right away and usually these
bones will just sort of pop right out
and just shred it into bite-sized pieces
this is looking close as well it's
starting to thicken up nicely I think it
needs maybe one or two more minutes
before we put the chicken back in let's
check that pot one more time okay that's
looking nice and thick now we can put
the chicken back in and again any
accumulated juices in that bowl get
those back in there too that's all
flavor and because everything's fully
cooked at this point we really just want
the chicken to be warmed through again
and then we're ready to serve it how
beautiful is this chicken chili stew to
serve it ladle some into a bowl and then
finish it off with a little lime juice
and cilantro you could serve this with
tortilla chips with cornbread fresh
tortillas nice and warm and just for
presentation squeeze of fresh lime juice
and lots of fresh cilantro for me I love
cilantro I have to try this right away
it looks and smells so delicious mmm
rich wonderful flavor do make this
chicken chili stew for your next
gathering no one will be disappointed I
promise
you
